content.description:
If you don't have strong fingers, this route will let you know. Not a long one but intense.

In front of the trail that leads to the crag.

Bolts + anchor. stick-clip

Follow the obvious flake with a wolf's head shape. You cant miss it.



Spot the obvious flake with a wolf's head shape (white flake on a black face).

2 bolts + trad + rap station

The route starts left of the first bolt. Better stick clip it. Quite easy up to the third bolt then a super short but intense crux is waiting for you. 
 In its original version, you had to use a small hold to go left and then up to the easier section. The route has been called a 5.13a. 
 The middle key hold in the crux broke and people said it became 5.13b but a version going right has been found which brought it back to 5.13a. 
 In May 2016, the exit right hand hold broke and it's now much harder. The route might be back at 5.13b but who knows!!!

Starts on top of the large ramp
One bolt, 4 fixed draws + anchor

Start under an overhanging dihedral, left of a vertical white line on the rock, traverse right until you are under the first bolt, than go up, exiting on the slab with just enough holds. Finish on a large ledge.



The upper half is a distinguishable slab with black rock. 

5 bolts + rap station

Hard to read from the ground. Some of the holds that look bad are good and vice-versa. Fight the pump and save some for the last move.

Superbe voie de jug en endurance parfait pour les gym climber. Le crux viens très top à la première bolt. Rendu à la deuxième tout se transforme en jug jusqu’à une petit mouvement un peu plus haut vers la fin. Cette voie est 5 étoiles. 



Right in front of the trail that leads to the cliff. The line follows a diagonal from the start to the the top.


Bolts + anchor+ stick clip

Hard to onsight due to bolts location versus holds that are hard to find. The falls might be intimidating in places but they're all good if the belayer pays attention. Pulling the roof was the hard part for me. If you exit too much to the left, you end up being in Oksos and I would say that it makes it 5.12a.

Almost in front of the trail that leads to the crag. Look for a dihedral/roof.
Bolts + anchor

Climb the Juggy flake and clip the third draw before commiting to the crimp fest overhang. After the first crux, find the good hold to clip the fourth draw and get on the tricky slab. Next, fiddle around and keep some energy for the last move !

Grimpez le feuillet de Juggs et clippez les trois premières dégaines avant d'engager vos mordants pour la face déversante. Après le premier crux, trouvez la bonne prise pour clipper la quatrième dégaine et engagez-vous sur la dalle technique. Fignolez la suite et conservez du jus pour le mouvement qui guette la fin !



The rightmost PermaDraw line of the sector, to the right of Géronimo and left of the «Wolf Head».

La ligne de PermaDraw la plus à droite du secteur, à droite de Géronimo et à gauche de «Geule de Loup»


6 Bolts to anchors

Don't climb this one with power. The more technique and finesse you will use, the easiest it will feel. You still need a bit of power for the top. In front of the trail that leads to the cliff.
Look for a line that does a traverse in the first part of the route. Bolts + anchor.

It's a really short one but easy to mess up the sequence making it harder.

First route of the crag. When you get to the cliff, turn left and walk about 75 feet.
3 bolts + anchor.

The name of the route means there are three cruxes and that the route stays dry all the time. Not easy to find out how to clip the anchor. Expect a few trial and error...

When the trail meets the cliff, turn left and go up just a little.
All sport but the anchor is a bit high and to the left. I would use a cam after the last bolt to reduce the length of the fall.
Best section to climb on a hot sunny day since the crag is in the sun most of the day. The belayer will be in the shade most of the time.
